Item.Item: Epson Stylus Photo R3000 Color Ink-jet printer - 120 sheets
Epson Stylus Photo R3000 Color Ink-jet printer - 120 sheets
Item.Review:
Pros: Superb photo prints, faster printing than the Epson R2880, can print on roll paper, CDs and DVDs, bigger ink tanks are more economical, uSB, Ethernet and Wi-Fi connectivity, auto-switching between photo and matte black ink
Cons: Wasteful ink purge during auto switching, expensive
The Epson Stylus Photo R3000 is an upgrade -- but not a replacement -- for the Epson Stylus Photo R2880, which is one of experts' favorite high-end photo printers. The R3000 fixes the R2880's biggest flaw, reviews say: You no longer have to manually switch the black ink tank every time you switch between matte and glossy paper (the R3000 now makes the switch automatically). ...

Item.Item: Epson Stylus Photo R3000 Color Ink-jet printer - 120 sheets
Item.Review:
Pros: Easy To Set Up
Cons: Large Footprint
I previously used an Epson R1800 which I was happy with except for the fact that I could see printer lines in skies in my photos. Now, I am talking about holding the print up to my nose and really staring. The other minor issue with the R1800 was that the clouds in most of my photos had a color cast. Also I was never happy with black and white photo results; too much metamerism and some color cast, therefore I never printed black and white. As well, if I was to print a sheet of text, I noticed that the characters were slightly misaligned; the letters looked a little jagged. I wondered if text was slightly jagged, is it really printing my photos as well as it should?Enter the R3000. Transitions in the sky are smooth (which they ... were on the R1800 as well). I might be able to see printer lines from the R3000 only if using a loupe. I also downloaded a test print photo. Print gradations on the test photo were incredibly smooth as well. I was really impressed when I saw no color cast at all in clouds in my photos. I wanted to see how vivid the printer will print, so I printed a photo of Hawaiian print clothing from the swap meet in Honolulu. Colors are vivid and true except for slight difference in the yellow. See that photo in this review.It has an advanced black and white mode in the driver where you can select neutral, cool, warm, and sepia. It works very well. If you want some tips on printing black and white, check out Eric Chan's tips here in his chart at the bottom before you print (chart is for Epson 3800 but also applies to R3000): http://people.csail.mit.edu/ericchan/dp/Epson3800/abwprofiles.htmlI printed a sheet of text; letters have no jaggies! They're perfect! If you print only glossy photos, perhaps better to stay with one of the printers that have a gloss optimizer. If you print glossy on the R3000, there is sheen differential in the areas that have little or no color. However, if you can live with that since the variations are hardly noticeable. In addition, you could spray the photo with a glossy spray.It seems to suck ink like a pig. In fairness, however, during the initial setup you lose a lot of ink. Admittedly, I have printed a lot since this is new for me. According to [@], the cost of ink to print an 8.5 X 11 for both the R1800 and the R3000 is about 70 cents.I was hoping that since the cartridges are roughly twice the size of the R1800, that they would cost less. The 3880, they say, is much more economical on ink. I had considered this printer as well. For me, though, the cost of the 3880 is so much higher than the R3000, it would take forever for me to make up the cost in ink saved. The other drawback of the 3880, for me, was that it takes two people to set it up because of the weight. The big advantage I see for the 3880 is the wider format, which is really nice. Cannot comment on matte paper nor fine art paper yet, since I haven't tried any of those yet.The R1800 certainly met most of my needs. Photography is just a hobby for me. The incentive for my getting the R3000 was the rebate until the end of September. I am glad I bought it. I can see where it can take my photos to a new level.There are two reasons why I only gave it 4 stars instead of 5 is because of the cost of the ink. Epson isn't giving you a discount for buying cartridges that are twice the size of the R1800, but they are giving the owners of the 3880 a "discount," proportionally, for buying larger. In addition to that, ink is wasted each time you change from photo black to matte black ink and vice versa. I think this waste of expensive ink is a travesty. As far as print quality, I can't imagine that it can get better. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Epson Stylus Photo R3000 Color Ink-jet printer - 120 sheets
Item.Review:
Pros: Fast Print Time; Durable construction; Reliable; Easy To Use

Great quality photo prints. Great inks. Wireless setup is difficult and time consuming. Setup with monitor and matching with photo papers is not straightforward. Inks are expensive.

Item.Item: Epson Stylus Photo R3000 Color Ink-jet printer - 120 sheets
Item.Review: It is a good quality printer, but only useful for small number of pictures. Each picture needs to be re-sized to match the paper size before printing. For example if you are printing a 4x6 print, you need to open the picture in something like Photoshop and resize the print to be 4x6 else the software will print just the top left part of the picture. I called Epson customer service and was told the fit to page option does not resize the print by design. They assume that if the user is using an advanced printer they don't want to change the print in any way. To me that is a bug in their driver. They should give the user the option to do it manually or automatically. They said this is by design on the R3000. This printer is not for the person who just wants to print 20 or 30 quality pictures ... off of their camera. Each picture requires some work before printing. Epson customer service was great. I did not like their answers, but still they did a good job of answering my questions and even did some investigation and called me back. You cannot ask for better service than that. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Epson Stylus Photo R3000 Color Ink-jet printer - 120 sheets
Item.Review: I have owned the Epson Stylus R3000 for almost three weeks, so it's a bit premature for any final thoughts, but what I have seen so far, I like. The R3000 has done a superb job printing on Red River Aurora, Polar Matte, and Polar Gloss papers as well as Moab Colorado and Ilford Gold Fibre Silk. Colors are true and well-saturated, with a surprisingly good image on glossy papers. Black and white is deep and well-defined, and the R3000 solves an issue I had with my previous brand C pro printer where black and white images printed with varying shades of a green tint. This is a true higher resolution printer and it rewards your efforts to shoot a tack-sharp image. The black ink swapping is reasonably painless, as the R3000 selects glossy or matte once you choose the paper's ICC profile and pr ... int. If you turn on the printer and send a print job that requires an ink swap, though, the R3000 does chug and whirr for a few minutes and a screen pop-up lets you know it's changing ink tanks. Paper handling has been faultless so far, and 13 x 19 sheets have fed with ease through the front paper path. I have not yet had occasion to use the roll-fed option as I prefer not having to deal; with paper curl. The size and weight the R3000 seem unremarkable; it's actually a couple of inches narrower than the printer it replaced. Nice, solid build as well. I know that the C brand pigment printer is a strong competitor, but I decided that I didn't want to deal any longer with its limitation on print length and its imposition of its own borders on fine art paper. I really like the R3000 and I believe it is a great way to enjoy taking your photography to the next level. Highly recommended. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Epson Stylus Photo R3000 Color Ink-jet printer - 120 sheets
Item.ReviewTitle: Great photos, easy setup, big footprint!
Item.Review: My former Epson photo printer just outright died and I was desperate for something new and easy to use. After researching printers, I decided that I didn't need to go bigger and more expensive so chose the R3000. The setup was easy and I love the wifi option - the fewer cords the better. The only negative so far is the bigger footprint. It takes up more room than my previous Epson that printed the same size prints. Not sure why it has to be so big but...love the prints!

Item.Item: Epson Stylus Photo R3000 Color Ink-jet printer - 120 sheets
Item.Review: I have just started doing photographs of birds and insects primarily flying or in motion. The color photographs I have produced so far have exceeded my expectations with the detail and subtle differences in colors and textures of the birds clearly and accurately reproduced. For the flying insects their intricate patterns of colors and textures and the richness of the flowers and vegetation they land on is vividly reproduced. For the money this is a great printer. Setup was quick with easy to follow directions; I was printing my first photo within an hour of unpacking the printer. As with most people's experience of this printer the biggest down side is the flushing of ink when changing to matte ink. I would definitely recommend this printer to anyone interested in producing display qualit ... y photographs. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Epson Stylus Photo R3000 Color Ink-jet printer - 120 sheets

Item.Review: This is my primary photo printer with photoshop 10. Got it because of perminant nature of pigment inks and reliability. After some set up issues, it is now working great. Had to figure out that that mode had to be set to ICM to get it to look like what I saw on my monitor. Wasted a lot of pictures before I figured that out. Certain colors of ink do run down faster and have to use Epson papers to get the quality I want. In the end the quality of the images are worth the fact that thge ink runs down faster than I would like.

Item.Item: Epson Stylus Photo R3000 Color Ink-jet printer - 120 sheets

Item.Review: I am a novice photographer who is picking up this previous hobby since I retired. I purchased a Canon EOS 60D camera and wanted a good printer. First let me say that it was simple to setup and use with wifi. The quality of the print exceeded my expectations and printing using different sizes of paper could not be any more straight forward. The only downside (if there is one) is the price of the ink. I am finding that I need to conserve on what I print so that I do not run down the ink. Overall, I love the printer and the quality.

Item.Item: Epson Stylus Photo R3000 Color Ink-jet printer - 120 sheets

Once I started honing in on everything written that I could find about this printer, I had no hesitation whatsoever in purchasing said printer. Once received, I could not have been more delighted with everything involving the R3000. Setup and software installation was a breeze... it could not have gone any easier. But my shear joy came once I started printing. The results were spectacular as the colors were brilliant, the detail was spectacular, and the overa ... ll operation was excellent. I was a computer tech for 25+ years and have watched the evolution of both the PC and printer since their infancy. I have worked on printers during that entire time and know I own a quality product that will give me many years of superb printing that will far exceed the disaster I recently experienced. Thank you Epson! expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Epson Stylus Photo R3000 Color Ink-jet printer - 120 sheets
Item.ReviewTitle: A fine machine and a terrible driver
Item.Review: First thing first. Color management in a tough coogie. If you believe that buying the best printer in the world will give wonderful color and B&W pictures right out of the box you are ready for a big disappointment. Good color and B&W pictures is a result of several factors, such as, a well calibrated monitor, lighting and even a viewing light that must be at least similar to the lighting condition under which the picture will be displayed. After several years I have settled for X-rite i1display Pro and Epson Ultra Premium Photo Paper Luster and Epson printer with pigmented ink. Before reviewing the printer, the bad things. I tried to install it for wireless use using the USB method. After three computers failed to install it I talked to the Tech Support, which is not a toll ... free number and the technician was as mystified as I was. Fortunately, the printer's screen provide another method of installation and this worked perfectly and flawlessly. Technical Support however could not solve it. To test the printer I used two pictures included in the driver CD ROM and the result were nothing short of amazing. However, I noticed that an old foe popped-up: Bronzing. Bronzing is a picture effect in which, if you tilt a paper picture in certain angle with respect to a light source, certain colors appear as a stain rather than being part of the image. It looks as if the color float on top of the image rather than being part of the image. When I called the technical support, they advised to bypass the entire Color Management technique to allow the printer to manage the color. This is astonishing! The whole concept of color management is to match the what you see on the screen with what you get out the printer. The printer is a peripheral and has no way to know what the monitor is showing you. The printer itself cannot decide what output will match your screen. I learned, way way back, that chasing color to match the screen and the printer can blow your cost out proportion. You waste the fine paper and your very, very very expensive inks pursuing a chance. That is one of the most important reasons to embrace Color Management. I followed the advise and, of course, the color was terrible off, and logically so. The technician could not explain the bronzing and how to mitigate it. This is still an issue. A more serious flaw is, however, the driver of the printer. A driver is a software element that is installed with the device to allow the computer to talk to the peripheral, in this case, the printer. Very few times have I've seen such a careless driver. This is the list of issues that I found: The paper is mentioned twice in the same driver, with different name. In the front ed is called SPR 3000 premium luster, but deep in another submenu is called Ultrapremium Photo Paper Luster. This submenu is labeled Print Settings, but, if you try to go there to review the settings it tells you that the primer does not exist. The only way that I found to re-enter is by switching to another printer momentarily and then re-select the R3000 again. At that point I already lost all the setting and the driver by default goes back to matte paper. This driver remembers nothing. If I want to print two copies of the same picture, after the printer finishes the first, it already forgot that I ordered two. You can print a second one, of course, but the driver will also forget your color setting and you have to go back the same routine: Chose another printer because the driver does not recognize the printer the second time around, reselect the R3000 and you will need to re-enter all the color options. Every single copy is an exercise of patient. There are other less irritating issues, for example, I have found no way to erase a configuration that was wrong or I no longer need, the driver does not tell me how much ink do I have in the cartridges, etc. Of course, every time that you forget one of those little things the resulting color is completely off. Despite an irritating and cheap, cheap driver, my testing in... expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Epson Stylus Photo R3000 Color Ink-jet printer - 120 sheets
Item.ReviewTitle: Great Pix, Beware the Ink Consumption
Item.Review: This printer replaced a 2200 that I had used with pleasure for many years. Be advised that it is exclusively a photo printer, not a general purpose color printer. It produces much better quality prints than the 2200 and it is much easier to set up and use. I am happy with the purchase BUT... Get ready for a new dimension in ink consumption. The larger cartridges do not mean longer times between refills--they are large because you will simply use much more ink. Believe every word that other reviewers say when they complain about the ink consumption. It is immediately apparent even after producing the first few prints AND... Develop some patience because it takes noticeably more time for this model to cycle up and produce the first print than the 2200. NONETHELESS... This printer is certa ... inly the best value for moving up from lower-numbered Epson printers--if you want good quality photo prints. This is especially true if you print panoramas using roll paper because the next-up models only print sheets. 5 stars for the printer and 3 stars for the ink consumption makes this a 4 star rating. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Epson Stylus Photo R3000 Color Ink-jet printer - 120 sheets

Item.Review: Setup to use wireless, very easy and smooth. The CD/DVD printing function is very handy and important to me. Haven t used many features yet, but I believe it won t disappoint.

Item.Item: Epson Stylus Photo R3000 Color Ink-jet printer - 120 sheets
Item.Review: Very happy with this product. Quality is outstanding, price is very competitive. Ease of use with a great design. I upgraded from an Epson 2200. It gives better prints than the 2200.

Item.Item: Epson Stylus Photo R3000 Color Ink-jet printer - 120 sheets
Item.Review: To be fair, this is my first printer of this level. It was down to this or Canon's 9500mkII. After tons of research, I got the Epson. I've had it now for about 6 months. The prints are gorgeous - very impressive. Letting the printer manage color, with a little tweaking, actually works very well 90% of the time. Setup was pretty easy, and I love having the wi-fi instead of running yet another cable to my computer. It's about as big as expected but not overwhelming. Heavy but I was able to lift it from the box to table by myself without undue strain (I'm 5'7 female in reasonable but not epic shape). What I do NOT love, is the ink waste. And I don't mean while printing - that's acutally pretty good. On matte papers, I actually lower the ink density and use just the Quality setting now - d ... idn't see an appreciable difference from High Quality even looking very, very closely under bright light. Randomly (it seems) when I send a project to print it will spend about 7-10 minutes adjusting, whirring, and wasting ink. This is even if I've used it recently and leaving it in standby mode. And no, not while changing from matte to glossy blacks. I've watched ALL ink levels drop visibly when this happens. It is VERY frustrating watching $$$ disappear for no apparent reason. The nozzles can't possibly need that much cleaning! I called Epson with the issue to see if I needed to return/exchange the printer. He said the issue I described was not a known issue. He did his best to help, but ultimately, he didn't really have a specific solution to my concern (found more help on the dpreview forums) but did send a brand new set of inks to me without me having to ask. The problem seemed to subside for a while, but it's started doing it again today. Not sure if there's an external factor I'm not aware of - temperature is pretty consistent in the room and it's not overly dry. I print anywhere from several times a day to every couple of weeks. BUT, when it isn't wasting ink on whatever it's doing for those 7-10 minutes, it's a great printer - the end result is really beautiful. I will note, too, though that it seems to struggle a little with highly saturated, deep blues, but I believe that may be something normal as blues can be difficult to reproduce in gamut. The reds are great though! Would I get another Epson? I can't say for sure. I'd like to get a wide-format printer eventually, and who knows what will be available by the time I'm actually able to buy one. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Epson Stylus Photo R3000 Color Ink-jet printer - 120 sheets
Item.Review:
Pros: Great Functionality; Easy To Set Up; Easy To Use; Durable construction; Reliable
Cons: Price
Was fed up with bad color and media jams using cheaper printers, but didn't know if this pricey printer would be worth it. So far I'm happy. This printer is easy to set up and has a ton of functionality. It has no problem handling strange paper sizes or thick card stock. The feed mechanism is awesome - when I choose a border around my print it is perfect. And the color is amazing. If I can imagine an end result, this printer can produce it. I have not used it long enough to comment on ink consumption, and have also not used the B&W mode.

Item.Item: Epson Stylus Photo R3000 Color Ink-jet printer - 120 sheets
Item.ReviewTitle: Great printer! Minor paper size problem
Item.Review: Just replaced my Epson R2880 with the R3000. Over 90% of my printing is of photographs and never having to swap Photo and Matte Black ink cartridges when changing paper types is wonderful! Paper handling for thicker paper has improved. The larger ink cartridges are nice, but won't save you much money over the smaller R2880 cartridges. Printed images are superb, but that was true with the R2880 as well. I have a problem with Moab Entradalopes. The paper is 7 x 10 and the profile from Moab uses a Fine Art media type which forces the use of the front paper loader. The front paper loader has a minimum paper size of 8.27 x 11. My solution is to ask Moab support to suggest an alternate media type that uses the sheet feeder and I will make my own profile using a Colormunki when I hear bac ... k from them. Be aware that the minimum page size for media types that use the front paper loader is 8.27 x 11 and that you can't override where to load the paper as you could with the R2880. I would have given a five star rating if it wasn't for this limitation. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Epson Stylus Photo R3000 Color Ink-jet printer - 120 sheets
Item.Review:
Pros: Easy To Set Up; Easy To Use; Durable construction
Cons: Too much ink used
After extensive research and reading other reviews I chose this printer and I'm not disappointed. The ability to connect via Wi-Fi was very important to me and the $150 rebate was an added incentive. It is a very sturdy well constructed and a very quiet printer, so quite you don't even know it is running. Setup was fast and easy.
I have used the Epson R3000 for a few weeks and a few dozen photos, it was easy to install and although the printer settings can easily be tweaked, the default settings work very well right out of the box. The quality in the color of my printed photographs is the best of any printer I've ever owned.
I love the ability to change from photo black to matte ... black. The only thing that chaps me about this printer is the amount of ink that gets lost due to switching from matte black to photo black or vice versa considering the high cost of the R3000 ink cartridges.
I am very happy with this purchase. It is a great printer and I would highly recommend it to anyone interested in a printer that prints very high quality photos. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Epson Stylus Photo R3000 Color Ink-jet printer - 120 sheets
Item.Review: I ordered this printer on a Monday and it arrived Thursday. I have been researching ink jet printers for a year now and finally settled on the Epson R3000, for it's price and for all of the positive reviews I have read. I'm particularly interested in its black and white capabilities so that I can print old negatives that I have scanned. It's still pretty early, as far as my experience with this printer but so far, I'm pleased with its performance. I have spent quite a bit of time calibrating my monitor and making test prints. A little more tweaking of my image files and I believe I'll be there. Can't wait to print my color work!

Item.Item: Epson Stylus Photo R3000 Color Ink-jet printer - 120 sheets

Item.Item: Epson Stylus Photo R3000 Color Ink-jet printer - 120 sheets
